--- Test For Success ---

Once requirements are understood, the methods for verification shoud be defined. These methods must include specific test procedures to be used, the units of measure, and the acceptance criteria.

There are several categories of testing done in product development.

  • Development Testing Testing done to understand the limits of the design space. Tests should be designed so that limits are reached about half the time to maximize information obtained. This way, design constraints are best defined. Sample sizes and test counts need to provide a good statistical basis for drawing conclusions.
  • Verification Testing Testing done to verify that functional requiremenst are met. Test failures at this point should be rare and carefully evaluated if they occur.
  • Reliability Testing Testing done to determine and/or verify expected product life. Testing must be done to failue to be sure that product strengths are well understood.

Statistical significance should always be considered when designing test plans and evaluating the results. Consideration should be given to the following:

  • Sampe Size (n) Small sample size can contribute to design flaw escapes due to incorrect conclusions due to high Beta error. Beta error is inversly proportional to sample size
  • Minimum p-value for rejecting the Null Hypothesis This should be a business driven value where test cost is traded off for lower Alpha error

    continuous vs discrete.

    Normally distributed vs non-normal.
